title: Fuel Price To Fall
text:
16 July 2015 08:28 CET Fuel Price To Fall By Daily Guide 
The prices of petroleum products are expected to reduced by 24 percent per the computations of the Chamber of Bulk Oil Distributors. 
This has been occasioned by the recent fall in the price of crude oil on the world market and the appreciation of the local currency against major foreign currencies lately. 
Senyo Horsi, Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the Chamber of Bulk Oil Distributors, in an interview with BUSINESS GUIDE said that prices of petroleum products are expected to go down but did not disclose the exact percentage reduction. 
Mr Horsi said the Chamber has never mentioned that fuel prices would go down by 24 percent from today. 
During a press briefing on the chamber's plans to publish petroleum price indicators in Accra, it explained that per its calculation the prices of the products should go down. 
According to him, the chamber was not responsible for fixing the prices of products on the market, adding that such a move was now at the behest of Oil Marketing Companies (OMCs), following the deregulation policy of the downstream petroleum sector as announced by the National Petroleum Authority (NPA). 
Even though the Chamber of Bulk Oil Distributors (CBODs) is expecting a reduction in the ex-refinery price of fuel products, one thing about the ex-refinery price indicator (XPI) that we should understand is that that is not necessarily what BDCs will also do. It is an indication of what fairly could be the case from the model that we have â€¦.' 
'BDCs may sell lower or may want to sell higher, they are at liberty but from our estimation and what we have seen in the market all this while, BDCs are likely to sell even lower than the XPI will show,' he explained. 
Mr. Horsi disclosed that the Ex-Refinery Price Indicator (XPi) and Oil Traders Index (OTi) would be published on the 1st, 8th, 16th and 23rd of every month, stating that 'it will be circulated in press releases as part of market reports emanating from the CBOD. 
Former CEO of the Volta River Authority (VRA), Dr. Charles Wereko-Brobby has also called for reduction of the prices of petroleum prices by 23 percent.
